metadata.title: Reduction of Natural Killer but Not Effector CD8 T Lymphoyctes in Three Consecutive Cases of Severe/ Lethal H1N1/09 Influenza A Virus Infection

abstract.original_text: Background: The cause of severe disease in some patients infected with pandemic influenza A virus is unclear.

sentences.segment_text: Background : The cause of severe disease in some patients infected with pandemic influenza A virus is unclear .

abstract.original_text: Methodology/Principal Findings: We present the cellular immunology profile in the blood, and detailed clinical (and postmortem) findings of three patients with rapidly progressive infection, including a pregnant patient who died. The striking finding is of reduction in natural killer (NK) cells but preservation of activated effector CD8 T lymphocytes; with viraemia in the patient who had no NK cells. Comparison with control groups suggests that the reduction of NK cells is unique to these severely ill patients.

abstract.original_text: Conclusion/Significance: Our report shows markedly reduced NK cells in the three patients that we sampled and raises the hypothesis that NK may have a more significant role than T lymphocytes in controlling viral burden when the host is confronted with a new influenza A virus subtype.
